metadata.abstractText: Chiral zeolitic imidazolate framework (ZIF) showing circularly polarized luminescence (CPL) has been successfully achieved through a ligand-exchange approach by blending a binapthyl-derived chiral emitters with ZIF-8 rhombododecahedron nanoparticles. This approach solves a major trade-off in CPL-active materials: large luminescence dissymmetry factor (glum) always suffer from supression of luminescence efficiency, due to the magnetic and electronic dipole transition nature. Compared with the optical properties of chiral emitters in dilute solution, the obtained chiral ZIF nanomaterials showed enhanced fluorescence efficiency (from 0.3 to 0.4) while the |glum| value also exhibited significant amplification by one-order of magnitude. In addition, the enantioselective fluorescence sensing in response to α-hydroxycarboxylic acids has also been enhanced in chiral ZIFs than the individual chiral emitters. The fact that reorganization and conjunction of chiral emitters to the skeleton of ZIF nanopaticles can greatly improve both luminescence quantum yield and circularly polarization which would facilitate the design of more efficient chiroptical materials. Chiroptical functional materials exhibiting circularly polarized luminescence (CPL) are attracting more and more interests due to their wide applications in various research field such as 3D optical imaging, chiral sensors, photoelectric devices and so on. To evaluate the level of CPL-active materials, luminescence dissymmetry factor (glum) and luminescence efficiency (ΦPL) are two critical important factors. Theoretically, glum is simply approximated by 4|m|cosθ / |μ| where |m| and |μ| are the magnitudes of magnetic and electric transition dipole moments vectors, respectively. Generally, large |μ| means high ΦPL but small glum, while large |m| will result in a high glum value with small ΦPL. To date, high value of glum could be obtained in chiral lanthanide complexes while low emission efficiency was always observed due to electric dipole-forbidden transitions. On the contrary, chiral organic molecules have strong luminescence but exhibit small glum values (10 -10) due to the large electric dipole transitions. To solve this trade-off issue between glum and ΦPL, people have developed some approaches to balance these two factors. Supramolecular self-assembly has been demonstrated as an effective approach for amplifying the glum, but assemblycaused quench of the fluorophore is hard to aviod. [7] Tang and co-workers had integrated two concepts of aggregation-induced emission (AIE) and CPL by covalently connecting chiral moieties with AIE-active fluorophores. Due to the on-off state of fluorescence in solution and solid state, CPL activity also could be lightened up in the solid state with a considerable glum value. Anyhow, exploring chiroptical systems with large glum value, while the emission efficiency could be preseved or even be enhanced, should be one of the most important issues in this research field. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), a subclass of coordination polymers with excellent porous property, have attracted much attention from researchers. Specially, endowing chirality to these materials, some excellent properties could be expected, like asymmetric catalysis, and enantioselective recognition or separation. Nevertheless, besides the excellent porous property, other properties of MOFs should not be negligible. For instance, as one of the most important porous materials, zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs) always exhibit rigid crystalline structures, extremely flat facets, and controllable nanoscale size. We envisage that these properties make ZIFs as an ideal platform for developing chiroptical materials. Traditional approaches for endowing ZIFs with chiroptical properties still faces huge challenges since the chiral moieties derived from imidazole require tedious organic synthesis process. Thus, ligand-exchange pathway would be an effective choice for chiral functionalization of the ZIFs. Here, we report the first example of the circularly polarized luminescent ZIFs with excellent enantioselective recognition for αhydroxycarboxylic acids through a ligand-exchange approach (Figure 1). Extensive studies about ZIF has been reported because of its potential applications in gas separation, storage, sensing and so on. However, very few cases about chiral ZIFs have been developed due to the tedious synthesis of enantiopure ligands and weak coordination and crystallization. In this work, we designed a pair of chiral emitters, based on binaphthyldiamine moiety with 4-(10-phenylanthrancen-9-yl)phenyl and functional imidazol groups (R-/S-1, Figure 1), which were found to emit circularly polarized light with a small |glum| value of 7.0 × 10 -4 in dilute solution.
